<oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/                          http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">
<dc:title>Matson photograph collection</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Matson Photo Service, photographer.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>American Colony (Jerusalem). Photo Dept., photographer.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>World War, 1914-1918--Middle East.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Christians--Middle East--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>British--Middle East--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Muslims--Middle East--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Bedouins--Middle East--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Druzes--Middle East--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Jews--Middle East--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Arabs--Middle East--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Agriculture--Middle East--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Archaeological sites--Middle East--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Architecture--Middle East--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Clothing & dress--Middle East--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Factories--Middle East--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Health care--Middle East--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Commerce--Middle East--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Dwellings--Middle East--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Politics & government--Middle East--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Education--Middle East--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Manners & customs--Middle East--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Monuments & memorials--Middle East--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Transportation--Middle East--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Travel--Middle East--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Palestine--History--1799-1917.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Palestine--History--1917-1948.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Sudan--1930-1940.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Uganda--1930-1940.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Zanzibar--1930-1940.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Kenya--1930-1940.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Tanzania--1930-1940.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Middle East--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Egypt--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Iraq--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Saudi Arabia--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Lebanon--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Syria--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Israel--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Jerusalem--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>West Bank--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Gaza Strip--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Jordan--1890-1960.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Africa--1930-1940.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>Pictures documenting peoples, places, and events in the Middle East from the last years of the Ottoman Empire, through World War I, the British Mandate period, World War II, and the emergence of the State of Israel. The majority of the images depict Palestine (present day Israel, the West Bank and Gaza Strip). Other countries shown are Lebanon, Syria, Jordan, Iraq, Egypt, and Turkey. There is some coverage of East African countries including Sudan, Kenya, Tanzania, Zanzibar, and Uganda. Pictures portray religious ceremonies, daily life, arts and crafts, archaeological sites, schools, hospitals, vegetation historic buildings and sites, demonstrations and conflicts, important events, political leaders, and landscapes. Also included are aerial photographs, portraits, and posed pictures depicting Biblical scenes.</dc:description>
<dc:description>The relationship of the negatives to the transparencies and photographic prints is complex. A set of 11 albums used by the Matson Photo Service in their Jerusalem store include cropped images of 5,000 of the negatives. Two other albums "Air Views of Palestine" (LOT 12016 ) and "Easter services in Church of the Holy Sepulchre, 1941" (LOT 13765) are also reproduced from negatives. Many of the 35mm slides, lantern slides, transparencies, and other photographic material were probably made from the negatives at some point as well. In some cases, the original negatives have not been found in the material held by the Prints and Photographs Division. In these instances, the photographic prints or the transparencies may be the only version of a particular image.</dc:description>
<dc:description>A supplementary archive includes: published catalogs, logbooks, and caption lists; booklets for slide sets, glass finlay screens, and examples of Matson Photo Service slide set boxes. A complete list of items in the supplementary archive is found in the Matson Collection collection file.  For more information on the catalogs and registers see: http://lcweb2.loc.gov/pp/matpchtml/matpcbib.html</dc:description>
<dc:description>LOT 12021 is a microfilm copy of Eric Matson's diaries (1908, 1919, 1921, 1922-23, 1924, 1935, 1942, 1943, and 1946). Original diaries transferred to LC Manuscript Division.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Materials transfered to Manuscript Division ( Papers of G. Eric Matson):  Eric Matson's diaries for 1908, 1919, 1921, 1922-23, 1924, 1935, 1942, 1943, 1946, 1947-1977, Eric Matson's correspondence files from 1946-1977, a business ledger from the American Colony Photo Department and the Matson Photo Service, and a map of Jerusalem published by Vester & Co. Three color films were transferred to the Motion Picture, Broadcasting, and Recorded Sound Division.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Unprocessed visual materials include: glass and film negatives of Matson family, friends and associates (PR6 CN 139), and copy prints of Matson negatives made by Eric Matson and the Library of Congress (PR09 CN 139).</dc:description>
<dc:description>For unprocessed portion of the collection: Please allow fourteen days advance notice to view materials. To make a request, see "Access to Unprocessed Materials," http://www.loc.gov/rr/print/info/022_unpr.html</dc:description>
<dc:description>Hobart, George S. "The Matson Collection: A Half Century of Photography in the Middle East." In A Century of Photographs, 1846-1946 Selected from the Collections of the Library of Congress, compiled by Renata V. Shaw, 1980, pp. 109-129</dc:description>
<dc:description>Special collections in the Library of Congress / compiled by Annette Melville. Washington, D.C. : Library of Congress, 1980, no. 157</dc:description>
<dc:description>Images were created by the American Colony Photo Department (1898-1940), which was located in Jerusalem and its successor firm, the Matson Photo Service (1940-1977), run by G. Eric and Edith Matson. For information on the American Colony Photo Department and the Matson Photo Service see: http://lcweb2.loc.gov/pp/matpchtml/matpcac.html</dc:description>
<dc:description>Gift; G. Eric and Edith Matson; 1966-1977.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Gift; Kensington Episcopal Home; 1978-2003.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Collection profile with information about the Matson Collection and a bibliography is available online http://lcweb2.loc.gov/pp/matpchtml/matpcabt.html</dc:description>
<dc:description>A set of catalog records describing each item is available through the Open Archives Initiative Protocol for Metadata Harvesting. See http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gdc/lcoa1.about</dc:description>
<dc:date>1898-1954, bulk 1898-1946</dc:date>
<dc:type>image</dc:type>
<dc:type>still image</dc:type>
<dc:type>collection</dc:type>
<dc:type>Aerial photographs</dc:type>
<dc:type>Landscape photographs</dc:type>
<dc:type>Photographic prints</dc:type>
<dc:type>Photograph albums</dc:type>
<dc:type>Autochromes</dc:type>
<dc:type>Glass transparencies</dc:type>
<dc:type>Film transparencies</dc:type>
<dc:type>Lantern slides</dc:type>
<dc:type>Slides</dc:type>
<dc:type>Film negatives</dc:type>
<dc:type>Dry plate negatives</dc:type>
<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.matpc</dc:identifier>
<dc:language>eng</dc:language>
<dc:coverage>Palestine</dc:coverage>
<dc:coverage>Sudan</dc:coverage>
<dc:coverage>Uganda</dc:coverage>
<dc:coverage>Zanzibar</dc:coverage>
<dc:coverage>Kenya</dc:coverage>
<dc:coverage>Tanzania</dc:coverage>
<dc:coverage>Middle East</dc:coverage>
<dc:coverage>Egypt</dc:coverage>
<dc:coverage>Iraq</dc:coverage>
<dc:coverage>Saudi Arabia</dc:coverage>
<dc:coverage>Lebanon</dc:coverage>
<dc:coverage>Syria</dc:coverage>
<dc:coverage>Israel</dc:coverage>
<dc:coverage>Jerusalem</dc:coverage>
<dc:coverage>West Bank</dc:coverage>
<dc:coverage>Gaza Strip</dc:coverage>
<dc:coverage>Jordan</dc:coverage>
<dc:coverage>Africa</dc:coverage>
<dc:rights>No known restrictions for the bulk of the collection. Publication may be restricted for glass lantern slides. For information, see "G. Eric and Edith Matson Photograph Collection" [http://www.loc.gov/rr/print/res/258_mats.html]</dc:rights>
</oai_dc:dc>

<oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/                          http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">
<dc:title>Woody Guthrie and the Archive of American Folk Song : correspondence, 1940-1950.</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Archive of American Folk Song.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. National Digital Library Program.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Guthrie, Woody,--1912-1967--Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Composers--United States--Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Folk singers--United States--Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>American Memory web site that highlights letters between Woody Guthrie and staff of the Archive of American Folk Song (now the Archive of Folk Culture, American Folklife Center) at the Library of Congress. The letters were written primarily in the early 1940s, shortly after Guthrie had moved to New York City and met the Archive's assistant in charge, Alan Lomax. Provides browsing letter titles and subject (including names of correspondents). Also includes a biographic sketch of Guthrie by Mark Allan Jackson, chronology, selected discography, and bibliography.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Title from home page (viewed on Feb. 9, 2006).</dc:description>
<dc:publisher>[Washington, D.C.] : Library of Congress</dc:publisher>
<dc:type>text</dc:type>
<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/collafc.af000013</dc:identifier>
<dc:language>eng</dc:language>
</oai_dc:dc>

<oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/                          http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">
<dc:title>The Kraus Collection of Sir Francis Drake</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Hans and Hanni Kraus Sir Francis Drake Collection (Library of Congress)</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Drake, Francis,--Sir,--1540?-1596--Sources.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Explorers--Great Britain.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Explorers--Spain.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Hans and Hanni Kraus Sir Francis Drake Collection (Library of Congress)</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Great Britain--History, Naval--Tudors, 1485-1603.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Great Britain--History--Elizabeth, 1558-1603.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>Sir Francis Drake, English explorer and naval strategist, circumnavigated the earth from 1577-1580. During these travels, Drake visited the Caribbean and the Pacific claiming a portion of California for Queen Elizabeth and waging battles on the Spanish. This collection comprises important primary and secondary materials accumulated about Drake's voyages throughout the then Spanish territory of the Americas. Texts are in English, Latin, German, Dutch, Italian, Spanish and French.</dc:description>
<dc:type>text</dc:type>
<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.rbc/collrbc.rb000009</dc:identifier>
<dc:language>eng</dc:language>
<dc:coverage>Great Britain</dc:coverage>
</oai_dc:dc>
keys: Hans and Hanni Kraus Sir Francis Drake Collection (Library of Congress)

documents.resource_data:
<oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/                          http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">
<dc:title>Before and after the great earthquake and fire early films of San Francisco, 1897-1916 /</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. Motion Picture, Broadcasting, and Recorded Sound Division.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. National Digital Library Program.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Earthquakes--California--San Francisco.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Fires--California--San Francisco.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>San Francisco Earthquake and Fire, Calif., 1906.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>City and town life--California--San Francisco--History.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>San Francisco (Calif.)--History.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>Site offers a perspective on the effects the San Francisco earthquake and subsequent fires of 1906 had on the development of the city. Seventeen films shot before the devestating events and seven shot detailing the horrendous damage are available for viewing. In addition a 1915 and 1916 film are included to illustrate the rebuilt area.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Title from Web page (viewed on Feb. 9, 2006).</dc:description>
<dc:description>Offered as part of the American Memory online resource compiled by the National Digital Library Program of the Library of Congress.</dc:description>
<dc:publisher>Washington, D.C. : Library of Congress</dc:publisher>
<dc:date>1999</dc:date>
<dc:type>image</dc:type>
<dc:type>moving image</dc:type>
<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.mbrsmi/collmbr.mi000001</dc:identifier>
<dc:language>eng</dc:language>
<dc:coverage>San Francisco (Calif.)</dc:coverage>
</oai_dc:dc>
keys: San Francisco Earthquake and Fire, Calif., 1906.
